bibl.title: Letter from Walter D. McCaw to Howard A. Kelly, October 21, 1922

div1.p: McCaw writes about memorials to Walter Reed, including the U.S. Army hospital in Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Walter D. McCaw to Howard A. Kelly, October 21, 1922
div1.opener:
IN REPLY REFER TO S.G.O._____________________
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
October 21, 1922.
wdm emc
S.G.O. 201 Reed Walter
Dr. Howard A. Kelly
1406 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
My dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
In answering your inquiry to the Superintendent,
Walter Reed Hospital, I have to say that this hospi-
tal is a U. S. Army General Hospital and is named in
honor of Walter Reed, following the custom of the War
Department with other general hospitals. To this ex-
tent only is it a memorial hospital to General Major Reed
and his work. The name was given it on the recommen-
dation of the Surgeon General's Office, by order of
the Secretary of War, per General Orders No. 172,
War Department, Washington, October 18, 1905. It is
the largest general hospital in the Army and cares
for all classes of sickness and injury. The Surgical
Service is especially important and cases are sent
for operation and treatment from all parts of the
United States. The average number of patients at
Walter Reed Hospital at the present time is 750.

As far as I know there has been no memorial
erected to Walter Reed at Panama.

A new building for the Army Medical School is
now under construction on the grounds of Walter Reed
Hospital and it is hoped eventually, although many
years may pass before it is an accomplished fact,
that the Army Medical Museum and Library will be re-
moved to that reservation in suitable buildings,
for which appropriations it is hoped may be obtained,
and that Walter Reed Hospital may become the Walter
Reed Medical Center and an institution of great
national, and even international importance.

It might be of interest to add that the Walter
Reed Memorial Association, which was organized in
ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON GENERAL, U.S. ARMY, WASHINGTON, D. C.”
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
this city and of which President Gilman, of Johns
Hopkins University, was the first President, collect-
ed from the friends and admirers of Walter Reed be-
tween twenty five and thirty thousand dollars, which
amount is now in the possession of the American Trust
Company, of this city, the interest being paid to
Mrs. Reed for life. At her death the money will be
available for erecting some form of memorial to Wal-
ter Reed.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Walter D. McCaw,
Acting Surgeon General.
